narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Sarah Rae Osterhoudt  Sarah Osterhoudt

Instructor: Sarah Rae Osterhoudt  Sarah was wonderful. She's incredibly thoughtful, observant and insightful. Sarah was a really great addition to class discussion and handled all of the technical aspects of the class effectively.

Instructor: Sarah Rae Osterhoudt  sarah is perhaps the best teaching assistant i've had here at FES. the department would be doing extremely well if it hired her as a professor here. she is brilliant, thoughtful, experienced, creative, supportive, and easy to access.
Instructor: Sarah Rae Osterhoudt  Sarah is the best.
Instructor: Sarah Rae Osterhoudt  Sarah Osterhoudt

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 1 - - I found the readings from the first half of the semester more engaging than the readings from the 2nd half.Question 6 - - Sarah is an excellent, responsive, highly competent TA. I also really loved her lecture the last time we met.Questions 13, 14 - - Just look the readings, I found the course overall excellent, but better in the first half than the second half.

really this was an excellent class, in large part because the group, as stewarded by professor dove and sarah, just worked so well together. discussions were so much fun, and i felt like i learned and grew in this class as much as any i took while at yale. however though the class was excellent, there is room for improvement. first of all, the title being a bit of a misnomer is not a small problem. there is a lot more room to address disasters as real, current, material phenomena, and not just sort of circle around their historical or theoretical construction. as for dystopia, there could have been a significant amount more material and discussion of that concept. i felt it was largely ignored or that its perimeter was traversed, not its literary or intellectual terrain. the real focus of this class, instead, was degradation, indigenous vs. colonial mythologies, and, the reach of surveillance and biopower. all of those can be wrapped into a way of understanding future dystopias (or our current one), however, the class may have benefited from diving into literature that depicted or theorized it directly.
Only about half the classes were on disaster, degradation, or dystopia, which was frustrating to students who signed up hoping to learn more about those three topics.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: - - Some great readings, especially early on.- - A strong group of students.- - Really hard issues and problems.- - The feeling that this course really built on, rather than repeated, the material and the concepts of other social ecology courses at FES.
Class discussion.
the discussions, the group. dove's and sarah's patience and articulatations of the material.
Sarah and Zerner's classes were great, as were some of the others that focused on disaster and degradation.
Class discussion

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: - - Some of the readings on Linnaeus, some of the readings by Frake, and some of the readings by Dove could be replaced.- - I really liked how in Agrarian Societies, the lecture was certainly tied to the readings, and helped us think about them, but wasn't exactly ON the readings. Then, in discussion, we dealt with the readings themselves, with the lecture we'd just heard shedding some new light. I think a similar system would work well in this course. At times, it felt like the lectures repeated the readings, making points that we then would come back to yet again in the discussion. Either that, or the lecture would cover all the points we'd meant to discuss, leaving the discussions a bit wandering. This is by no means a a huge issue and probably only happened a few times, but I thought I'd offer thissuggestion of a slight structural change.
The Linnaeus week.
apart from what was already stated, perhaps nothing.
Please don't assign the Frankel articles to another class!

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Sarah is a great TA, a thoughtful grader, and a wonderful lecturer and writer. Thanks!
Instructor: Sarah Rae Osterhoudt  Keep up the great work!

Instructor: Sarah Rae Osterhoudt  as a teaching assistant, sarah had no weaknesses that i can list. she has strengths, and these outdo any shortcoming she might have (none of which were apparent to me). she is supportive and accessible. she knows the material better than anybody. she doesn't simply know the material but has a peculiar and thoughtful take on it that contributes to and shapes rich discussions. her presence in the classroom and her help outside of it made this class without her unimaginable.
Instructor: Sarah Rae Osterhoudt  She is wonderful and insightful and supportive and kind. Best TA I've had here.

Instructor: Sarah Rae Osterhoudt  Sarah was very accessible and offered excellent feedback on our writing and research proposals. She also asked excellent questions during class discussion and helped direct the conversation in a productive and insightful manner.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Offered really compelling theoretical readings and helped me to think about my research.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Knew I really enjoyed the professor and was interested in the content.
it seems self evident--professor dove on disasters with a group of students i love and respect. i loved every second and knew i would.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: met, yes, exceed, at times. however this was not the class i expected. though this is usually a recommendation, in this case, it's not. i wish it had more to do with what the title advertises.
I had been hoping for more of a focus on disaster narratives and their critiques.
Yes!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: the group work was pretty informal. there were no disadvantages. the advantages lied in simply learning the material a bit more fully.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it even if your work isn't on disasters. It'll make you think, and it'll put you and your work in discussion with excellent students, a great professor, and well-picked authors.
take it if you have the time to devote to an intellectually rigorous program and regularly contributing to the powerful discussions you have been missing in your other classes.
Have an open mind, be prepared to do a lot of reading and writing, and make sure to engage in conversation with the instructor, teaching fellow, and fellow classmates.
